articles.headline: Chicago’s Choice Points to a Democratic Divide the G.O.P. Hopes to Exploit
articles.snippet: The two mayoral candidates, both Democrats, are on opposite sides of the debate over crime and policing. Republicans, with an eye toward 2024, are watching closely.
articles.abstract: The two mayoral candidates, both Democrats, are on opposite sides of the debate over crime and policing. Republicans, with an eye toward 2024, are watching closely.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — For nearly three years, since the ebbing of the George Floyd protests of 2020, almost nothing has divided the Democratic Party like the issues of crime, public safety and policing, much to the delight of Republicans eager to center urban violence in the nation’s political debate.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Michael C. Bender

articles.headline: Student Loan Case Could Redefine Limits of Presidential Power
articles.snippet: It is not the first time that the Supreme Court has suggested that President Biden has overstepped his authority, but the case could curtail his ambitions.
articles.abstract: It is not the first time that the Supreme Court has suggested that President Biden has overstepped his authority, but the case could curtail his ambitions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One of President Biden’s most ambitious proposals — a $400 billion program to forgive student loan debt for 40 million Americans — could become the latest victim of a legal tug of war with the Supreme Court over the powers of the presidency.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Adam Liptak

articles.headline: Biden Challenged by Softening Public Support for Arming Ukraine
articles.snippet: Proponents of more aid fear that growing taxpayer fatigue toward shipping tens of billions of dollars overseas could undercut the war effort.
articles.abstract: Proponents of more aid fear that growing taxpayer fatigue toward shipping tens of billions of dollars overseas could undercut the war effort.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When he made his surprise wartime trip to the Ukrainian capital of Kyiv last week, President Biden reassured that country with great confidence that “the Americans stand with you.” But the question that remains unanswered is: For how long?

articles.headline: Leave Russia? A Year Later Many Companies Can’t, or Won’t.
articles.snippet: Not all Western companies packed up and left Russia after its invasion of Ukraine. Some say Moscow has tied their hands, while others choose to stay put.
articles.abstract: Not all Western companies packed up and left Russia after its invasion of Ukraine. Some say Moscow has tied their hands, while others choose to stay put.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Russia invaded Ukraine, a phalanx of Western companies pledged to get out fast from what had once been an important market. McDonald’s dismantled its golden arches after 32 years. The oil giant BP moved to divest its mammoth Russian investments. The French automaker Renault sold its factories for the symbolic sum of one ruble.

articles.headline: Oklahoma Wants to Be the ‘Next Texas.’ Imagine That.
articles.snippet: Long in booming Texas’ shadow, Oklahoma has been trying to make itself an appealing place to move — if people would just give it a try.
articles.abstract: Long in booming Texas’ shadow, Oklahoma has been trying to make itself an appealing place to move — if people would just give it a try.
articles.lead_paragraph: OKLAHOMA CITY — On a stifling July day, Elon Musk sat across from the governor of Oklahoma under a small white pop-up tent, a red Tesla flag waving from a short pole in an otherwise unadorned field.

articles.headline: When Clothes Fly Off, This Intimacy Coordinator Steps In
articles.snippet: Jessica Steinrock’s work on intimate scenes in film has come to prominence as the entertainment industry reels from the litany of sexual abuses brought to light by the #MeToo movement.
articles.abstract: Jessica Steinrock’s work on intimate scenes in film has come to prominence as the entertainment industry reels from the litany of sexual abuses brought to light by the #MeToo movement.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Transforming Spaces” is a series about women driving change in sometimes unexpected places.

articles.headline: Canadians Fume as Migrants Surge at Their Border
articles.snippet: A surge in illegal crossings from the United States has led to calls to shut down a rural road on the Canadian border.
articles.abstract: A surge in illegal crossings from the United States has led to calls to shut down a rural road on the Canadian border.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hélène Gravel’s house sits on Roxham Road near Canada’s most famous illegal border crossing, used by migrants leaving the United States to seek asylum up north. She has watched with increasing frustration as a bitter winter has failed to stanch record inflows and as New York City even began buying bus tickets for migrants headed her way.
